newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan MOF to support NCB reform along with BOJ.
newsitem.headline: Japan MOF to support NCB reform along with BOJ.

text.p: Japan's Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka told a news conference on Tuesday that the ministry will extend full support to Nippon Credit Bank Ltd's restructuring plan in cooperation with the Bank of Japan (BOJ).

He said in a statement that the Ministry of Finance on Tuesday asked the BOJ and a special body administering a fund to wind up failed finance firms for permission to use the fund to buy preferred stock to be issued by NCB.

MOF believes the resulting capital increase in NCB, as well as NCB's disposal of problem loans, "will substantially improve NCB's business foundation and will contribute to the stability of financial systems both at home and abroad," Mitsuzuka said.

"The ministry believes that NCB has sufficient potential to restructure itself and has taken such a step because failure to deal with the problem could cause major financial instability both within Japan and overseas," Mitsuzuka said in his statement.

After reading the statement, he told a news conference that he applauds the moves by NCB, as well as a merger plan announced earlier on Tuesday by two Hokkaido-based banks, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd and Hokkaido Bank Ltd.
He said that the credibility of NCB in the financial markets and trust in the safety of NCB's debentures would quickly be regained as a result of the increase in capital.

NCB has informed the ministry that it plans to ask long-term credit banks, banks with major shareholdings in NCB and life and non-life insurers with subordinated loans to NCB to buy new shares in the bank to offset a reduction in capital resulting from bad-loan disposal, Mitsuzuka said.

NCB, itself one of Japan's long-term credit banks, announced earlier on Tuesday a major restructuring programme that will mean the loss of 600 jobs, the sale of prime real estate and a withdrawal from major overseas markets.
The troubled bank also said that it would write off 460 billion yen in bad loans for the 1996/97 financial year that ended on Monday and post a parent current loss of 350 billion yen for the period.
